) Purpose: This section describes the procedures of the Return Preparer (RPO) for receiving and evaluating complaints against tax return Scope and and when applicable, referring the complaints to stakeholders. (
) Audience: These instructions are intended for employees of the RPO Complaint Referrals unit (hereafter “Complaint Referrals”). (
) Policy Owner: The Director, RPO, is responsible for the complaint program. (
) Program Owner: The RPO Complaint Referrals unit receives and complaints against return preparers, and when applicable, refers the com- plaints to stakeholders. (

) Primary Stakeholders: The offices whose employees perform work the complaint referrals program are: • Wage & Investment (W&I) • Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) • Criminal Investigation (CI) • Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) • Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) • Other RPO units (
) Program Goal: To timely evaluate all complaints against tax return (
) The Complaint Referrals unit receives and evaluates complaints against return preparers. of the (

) A complaint moves through the following four phases during processing: a. Intake - receiving and logging the complaint into inventory. Complaint b. Evaluation - reviewing the correspondence to determine if it meets deﬁnition of a complaint and assessing its merits for further action. c. Research and Resolution - analyzing the facts in the complaint, ing research, and determining the appropriate action to resolve the complaint. d. Closing – carrying out the selected resolution of the complaint, such issuing a compliance letter or sending the complaint to the IRS stakeholder. (

) The Return Preparer Database (RP Database) is an Access database with separate complaint module that houses the complaint inventory. All Preparer complaint processing are completed within the complaint module, assignment and reassignment of employee inventory. (
) Complaint Referrals uses a speciﬁc complaint numbering system to track complaint and identify its source. (
) The number assigned to each complaint is called a control number. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

25.20.1.3.1 (02-19-2021) Format of a Control Number
The third digit represents the source of the complaint, as follows:
All complaints, unless described below

• Complaints received in the *RPO Referrals Mailbox from a source other than Accounts Management Services • Complaints received from national tax preparation ﬁrms through an IRS National Account Manager • Complaints received from return preparers who contact the PTIN Information Line or mail corre- spondence to the PTIN Processing Center. The PTIN Processing Center creates an enforcement case in the Tax Professional PTIN System (TPPS) for these complaints and sends them to Complaint Referrals via email (not through the *RPO Referrals mailbox). • Complaints received by RPO Compliance analysts
Complaints received via ee-Fax
Complaints received from Accounts Management Services (AMS) via the *RPO Referrals mailbox

Example: 21-01000 is the one-thousandth complaint received in 2021 from a non- speciﬁc source. 21-70004 is the fourth complaint received in 2021 via ee-Fax. 20-90010 is the tenth complaint in 2020 to be added by a RPO Compliance analyst.

Complaints are divided into categories based on the nature of the allegation,

as follows: Complaint Category Description Theft of Refund • Negotiating a taxpayer’s refund check or diverting all or a portion of a refund into an unknown bank account, Refund Anticipation Loan, Refund Anticipation Check or debit card, or received the client’s refund at an address unknown to the client. • Providing a copy of the return to the client with direct deposit infor- mation that does not belong to the taxpayer. • Providing a copy of the return to the client that does not match the return ﬁled with the IRS in order to take the increased amount of the refund. Referrals 25.20.1 page 5 Complaint Category Description E-File Issues Electronically ﬁling a client’s return without following IRS rules, including e-ﬁling using the last pay stub, e-ﬁling a return without securing the taxpayer’s signature on Form 8879, and other e-ﬁle violations. This also includes a complaint about a preparer’s own e-ﬁle problems. Data Breach Incident Releasing PII into an untrusted environ- ment. It is generally the loss or release of PII held by a return preparer as a result of a system integrity issue or physical loss/theft. Identity Theft to Obtain a Using another’s identity to obtain a PTIN PTIN. Compromised PTIN A return preparer’s PTIN has been used by someone else. TPPS Count Mismatch Identiﬁcation of a compromised PTIN by a PTIN holder who noticed a discrep- ancy between the number of returns actually prepared and the number of returns indicated as prepared according to the PTIN holder’s online TPPS account. Not Deﬁned An allegation that does not correspond (requires managerial to a speciﬁc complaint type or category approval) as listed above. No Complaint Referrals An allegation made against someone Category other than a return preparer, or a complaint against a tax return preparer without an allegation. ) A Management Directive is a request from RPO management to conduct speciﬁc research on or provide information about a complaint, or a Directives that requires special handling and response. Management directives are generally sent to Complaint Referrals employees via email. (
) Log, scan and upload the complaint into the RP Database within one day. The manager will then assign the complaint for resolution. (

) If assigned a Management Directive, follow all phases of standard complaint processing, with the following exceptions: a. Identify the complaint as urgent in the RP Database. b. Resolve and close the complaint to the manager within two business days after assignment, or notify the manager if it cannot be closed that time. (
) Complaints alleging the following must be classiﬁed as urgent: • Speciﬁc illegal activity described in IRM
Complaints • Compromised PTIN, including TPPS count mismatch • Identity Theft to Obtain a PTIN • Data breach incidents (
) Do not rely on the complaint form checkboxes as the sole indication of urgency. The narrative and any attachments should be used to assist in the decision. (

) For urgent complaints, follow all phases of standard complaint processing, the following exceptions: a. Always select Preparer Misconduct as the complaint category for activity. b. Identify the complaint as urgent in the RP Database. c. Resolve and close the complaint to the manager within two business days after assignment, or notify the manager if it cannot be closed that time. (

) The possible resolutions of a complaint are: • Closed; No Treatment Required – either action is not warranted, or action may be warranted but taking action would not be effective the preparer is now deceased or out of business). • Compliance Letter – action is warranted, and the most effective treatment is determined to be a letter to the return preparer the speciﬁc behavior and, in some letters, to provide educational resources. • Referral Criteria Met – the complaint meets a stakeholder’s referral criteria and the complaint is closed to that business unit. • Referral Criteria Not Met – action is warranted, but the complaint did meet any stakeholder’s referral criteria. • Resolved; No Violation Conﬁrmed – no action is warranted because allegation(s) could not be conﬁrmed by research or the information provided. • Return Integrity and Correspondence Services Transfer – the meets criteria for a referral to RICS. • RPO Transfer – the complaint meets criteria for a referral to RPO pliance or RPO Suitability. • Return Preparer Previously Referred - the preparer has been referred a stakeholder within the past
months. (

) If there is no indication of an IRS action affecting the complainant’s refund, perform research to determine if the preparer diverted refunds into an owned or controlled by the preparer, or diverted refunds through a RAC, or debit card. (
) Use sound judgment to determine which type of research will be most effective. Some suggested research steps are to: a. Review transaction code
to see if a refund was issued. • If the refund was direct-deposited, the Direct Deposit (DD) indicator be “
” and the Refund Schedule Number (RSN) will end in “Z.” • Multiple transaction codes

may mean the refund was split into multiple accounts. b. Use IDRS CC IMFOBT to ﬁnd the routing and account number(s), if IDRS CC IMFOLT indicates the refund was issued electronically. Use IDRS CC DDPOL to identify all deposits made into a speciﬁc bank account. Multiple deposits made into one account are an indication the preparer is either negotiating client refunds, securing preparation fees, diverting refunds directly into an account controlled by the preparer. d. Compare the copy of the return provided to the taxpayer (if available) to the return ﬁled with the IRS to determine if the refund amounts and account numbers match. (

to see if a refund was issued. • If the refund was direct-deposited, the Direct Deposit (DD) indicator will be “
” and the Refund Schedule Number (RSN) will end in “Z.” • Multiple transaction codes

may mean the refund was split into multiple accounts. b. Use IDRS CC IMFOBT to ﬁnd the routing and account number(s), if IDRS CC IMFOLT indicates the refund was issued electronically. If the account number contains the taxpayer’s SSN, then this is part of a refund anticipation check (RAC) or refund anticipation loan (RAL). c. Use IDRS CC DDPOL to identify all deposits made into a speciﬁc bank account. Multiple deposits made into one account are an indication the preparer is either negotiating client refunds, securing preparation fees, diverting refunds directly into an account controlled by the preparer. d. Compare the copy of the return provided to the taxpayer (if available) to the return ﬁled with the IRS to determine if the refund amounts and account numbers match.
